{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3651495,"name":"","username":"tvini","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tvini/{size}/246358_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-12T12:21:41.324Z","cooked":"

I designed a custom swerve module in CAD, inspired by the MK5n (sub-20DP steel gears, layout dimensions, etc.) and WCPâ€™s X2t (wheel design, gear ratios, etc.). Iâ€™d really appreciate any feedback on the design, manufacturability, possible measurement issues, or general improvements I could make.

{394E4272-55B7-47B7-A53E-4E1A1FDA6027}591Ã—593 56.9 KB

{2833A047-004E-48B5-A504-A2326743B089}574Ã—606 57.3 KB

{7BE5FCF8-E73C-4628-BE8B-183AEF69296A}765Ã—576 71 KB

{831796FA-4B5B-48A2-9AE3-15479F240706}757Ã—580 71 KB

Just a quick size comparison with the MK5n and X2t:

image1037Ã—466 63.3 KB

image1026Ã—471 54 KB

CAD: Onshape
Feel free to evaluate any aspects you think are importantâ€”thanks a lot!

A few questions to start us off:

  1. Are you planning on building this swerve drive or was it a design challenge only?
  2. Did you have a particular set of rules or a design philosophy you followed when designing this?
  3. What were your manufacturing constraints when designing this? Any particular machines or processes that you wanted to focus on or learn more about?
  4. I see some standard gears and some gears integrated into a more complex/custom design. Are you reusing any parts from COTS swerve modules, or are you intending for them to be custom machined? Gear machining can be complex and expensive for low-volume production.
  5. Did you have any specific reason for using flanged bearings over radial bearings? Iâ€™ve seen many custom-machined designs use radial bearings only (SDS swerves included) because the flanged bearings are more expensive and they can machine retaining features into the parts to make flanges unnecessary.
  6. There is nothing modeled to prevent the bearings pictured below from sliding out the top during use. Are these going to be retained using something like Loctite 638 retaining compound? Or would flipping the flanges to the other side make more sense?

A couple of thoughts:
The highest plate is big and complicated for its function (outboard support and armor)
Thereâ€™s a LOT of posts; seems like more than you really need.
